etymology.description: 還(hái) ‘still; yet’ + 是(shì) ‘to be’ = ‘still be; nevertheless; remain the case’.
etymology.interpretation: Marks that a situation remains unchanged or persists despite time or expectation, often after a contrast. In suggestions, can soften a recommendation (had better/it’d be best).
etymology.simplification: 還 was simplified to 还 by retaining the walk radical 辶 and replacing the complex phonetic component with a simpler form to reduce strokes; 是 is unchanged.

examples.chinese: 我还是爱你(我還是愛你)。
雨停了(雨停了)，路上还是很滑(路上還是很滑)。
examples.pinyin: Yǔ tíng le, lùshang háishi hěn huá.
examples.english: The rain has stopped, yet the road is still slippery.

examples.chinese: 现在已经九点了(現在已經九點了)，他还是没到(他還是沒到)。
examples.pinyin: Xiànzài yǐjīng jiǔ diǎn le, tā háishi méi dào.
examples.english: It’s already nine o’clock, yet he still hasn’t arrived.
